top_categories.workout_context: 10,000ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
Crusher in the Tushar's High-altitude gravel, Paved climbs forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 69 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Crusher in the Tushar's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before July.
69 miles on mixed surface climbing with extended descents burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
At Crusher in the Tushar, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
145ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Base fitness for Crusher in the Tushar. Without this, the hard workouts break you down instead of building you up.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Crusher in the Tushar, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
10,000ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on mixed surface climbing with extended descents. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Crusher in the Tushar. Train it until it feels boring.
Low-cadence force work for 10,000ft of climbing. The slow, grinding ascents where you can't spin—you push.

race_overlay.heat: July in Beaver, Utah — July at 10,000+ feet means intense sun, thin air, and afternoon thunderstorms. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Crusher in the Tushar — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Crusher in the Tushar’s 69 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.altitude: Crusher in the Tushar with 10,000ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Altitude adaptation critical.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Crusher in the Tushar demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride mixed surface climbing with extended descents at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: high-altitude gravel, paved climbs, technical descents. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 69 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on VO2max, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 69 miles of mixed surface climbing with extended descents in Beaver, Utah.
